metadata.case_name: Second Additional Income-tax Officer, Guntur v. Respondents

facts.text: Two appeals on certificates under Article 133(1)(c) of the Constitution by the Second Additional Income-tax Officer, Guntur, against the common decision of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh in two Letters Patent appeals confirming decisions of a single judge ordering writ of mandamus to give effect to revised assessments under section 35 of the Income-tax Act against the respondents.
Proceedings related to assessment year 1950-51; respondent in Civil Appeal No. 410 of 1961 assessed as individual, respondent in Civil Appeal No. 411 of 1961 as Hindu undivided family.
Original assessments completed on January 22, 1952; shares of profits from two registered firms included in total assessable incomes; assessments of firms not completed by that date.
Assessment orders noted that action under section 35 would be taken when correct share income known.
Assessments of the two firms completed by order dated October 16, 1954, revealing higher aggregate shares of income from the firms for each respondent.
After notice under section 35, revised assessment orders made under section 35 with additional demand; penalty of Rs. 300 imposed under section 46(1) on respondent in Civil Appeal No. 411 of 1961.
Respondents moved High Court of Andhra Pradesh under Article 226 of the Constitution.
Department justified revised assessments under sub-section (5) of section 35, added by section 19 of Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953 (25 of 1953), effective from April 1, 1952.
Original assessments before April 1, 1952; assessments of firms and revised assessments after that date.

Learned single judge erred in thinking assessments of firms made before April 1, 1952, citing Lakshminarayana Chetty v. Income-tax Officer, Nellore; held reopening under section 35(5) without jurisdiction.

Divisional bench upheld single judge, stating point as whether assessments made before April 1, 1952, can be reopened under section 35(5); did not permit department to contend for first time that section 35(5) applies since firms assessed after April 1, 1952.
Respondents did not appear at the hearing in the Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether sub-section (5) of section 35 of the Income-tax Act, effective from April 1, 1952, applies to original assessments completed before April 1, 1952, even if assessments of firms were completed after that date.
Whether the note in assessment orders that action under section 35 would be taken made the original assessments provisional.
Whether rectification could be under section 35(1) as a mistake apparent from the record, or if the firm's record could be used.

petitioner_arguments.text: Revised assessments justified under section 35(5) since assessments of firms made after April 1, 1952.
Assessments of partners made on January 22, 1952, could be rectified under section 35(1) within four years, done after section 35(5) came into force.
Assessment of partners was provisional due to note that action under section 35 would be taken when firms' assessments completed.

court_reasoning.text: Single judge's error in date of firms' assessments explainable; relied on Lakshminarayana Chetty v. ITO Nellore holding reopening under section 35(5) without jurisdiction.
Divisional bench correctly framed issue; did not permit new argument on firms' assessment date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Case rested solely on section 35(5) in High Court; new point on section 35(1) not permitted in Supreme Court.

court_reasoning.text: Section 35(5) not retrospective; applies only from April 1, 1952; cannot apply to assessments completed before that date even if firms assessed after; limited retrospectivity, not procedural, affects vested rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fiction in section 35(5) deems certain mistakes apparent but power cannot be exercised for pre-April 1, 1952 partner assessments.

court_reasoning.text: Under pre-amendment law, firm's record not part of partner's record; no mistake apparent from partner's record under section 35(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Approved Kanumarlapudi Lakshminarayana Chetty; mistake from another record not apparent.

court_reasoning.text: Original assessments final, notwithstanding note on section 35 action; not provisional under section 23B.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Final assessment rectifiable only under then-existing law excluding section 35(5).

holdings.text: Sub-section (5) of section 35 cannot be applied to assessments completed before April 1, 1952.
Note in assessment order does not make assessment provisional; rectification only under law as it stood at completion.
No rectification under section 35(1) as no mistake apparent from assessee's record; firm's record extraneous.

precedents_cited.relevance: Section 35(1) limited to mistakes apparent from assessee's record; firm's record not included; section 35(5) not applicable to pre-April 1, 1952 assessments; not procedural, affects vested rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kanmarlapudi Lakshminarayana Chetty v. First Additional Income-tax Officer, Nellore
precedents_cited.relevance: Mistake from disposal of another case not apparent from record; section 35(5) fiction not out of abundant caution but to fill lacuna; not applicable to pre-April 1, 1952 firm assessments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshminarayana Chetty v. Income-tax Officer, Nellore
precedents_cited.relevance: Reopening under section 35(5) without jurisdiction (cited by single judge).

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs rectification of assessments; section 35(5) deems partner's share mistake apparent when firm assessed later, but limited to post-April 1, 1952; section 35(1) limited to apparent mistakes from assessee's record.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for appeals and writ petitions.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's decision that section 35(5) cannot be applied to original assessments completed before April 1, 1952; writ of mandamus directing Income-tax Officer to give effect to revised assessments set aside as without jurisdiction; appeals dismissed as High Court was right.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; High Court orders upheld in favor of respondents.

key_quotes.text: The assessment of the respondents was a final assessment before April 1, 1952, and sub-section 5 has not been made applicable to such assessment, either expressly or by implication.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on non-retrospectivity of section 35(5).

key_quotes.text: a mistake not apparent from such record could not be said to be made apparent from another record, which the record of the firm would be.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the provision enacted by sub-section 5 is not procedural in character and that it affects vested rights of an assessee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
